&app; is a chemistry elements periodic table application.

preface.title: Introduction
preface.para: The &app; application is a chemical elements periodic table application.

sect1.title: To Start &app;
sect1.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:

listitem.para:
Choose
Education Periodic table of the elements .

sect1.title: When You Start &app;
sect1.para: When you start &app;, the following window is displayed:
The &app; window contains the following elements:

listitem.para: The menus on the menubar contain all of the commands you need to work with &app;.
A periodic table of the elements. The colors used for the buttons are conventional colors for the elements. Other color schemes are available as explained there.

sect1.title: Color Schemes
sect1.para: Several color schemes are available:

listitem.para: The color of the button depends on the physical state of the element at a given temperature. This temperature can be changed using the horizontal scale.

abstract.para: Screenshot of the Main Page with Physical state color scheme.

listitem.para: Buttons with a black background indicate that the state is unknown at the given temperature.
The data used are the element family as given in the Blue Obelisk Data Repository. If no family is given in the database, the button will have a black background.

abstract.para: Screenshot of the Main Page with Physical state color scheme.

listitem.para: If a family is selected in the combo box, only elements of this family will be displayed with their family color used as background, other elements are attributed a black background.

varlistentry.para: The data used are the Pauling electronegativity as given in the Blue Obelisk Data Repository. Colors go from red (lowest electronegativity) to blue (highest electronegativity). If no data is available in the database, the button will have a black background.

abstract.para: Screenshot of the Main Page with Electronegativity color scheme.

listitem.para: The data used are the atomic radii as given in the Blue Obelisk Data Repository. Colors go from red (lowest radius) to blue (largest radius). If no data is available in the database, the button will have a black background.

abstract.para: Screenshot of the Main Page with Atomic radius color scheme.

varlistentry.para: Elements buttons are colored according to the block (s, p, d, or f) to which the element belongs

abstract.para: Screenshot of the Main Page with Block color scheme.

sect1.title: Element Window
sect1.para: This window shows the data for an element. To display it, press the corresponding element button in the periodic table. It is possible to display several such windows at once.
The data are spread over several pages, the following screenshots show the various pages for the iron element:

abstract.para: Screenshot of the Electronic Properties Page.
Screenshot of the Thermodynamic Properties Page.

sect1.para: When a Show curve button appears on the same line than a data, it is possible to display a chart of this data as a function of the element atomic number by clicking on the button.

sect1.title: Pre-defined Charts
sect1.para: When you click on the Show curve button in the you obtain a chart such as:

abstract.para: Screenshot of the first ionization energy curve.

sect1.para: Consecutive points are joined by a segment. The absence of a segment means that at least one data is missing.
Charts can be customized as explained in next section.

sect1.title: To Copy a Chart
sect1.para: To copy the chart, choose Edit Copy and paste in the target application. Charts will be copied as native graphs to Abiword and as svg or png data to other applications which support such formats.

sect1.title: To Export a Chart as an Image
sect1.para: To export the displayed chart to an image, use File Save As Image .
Available formats are SVG, EPS, PS, PDF, and the formats with write support in GdkPixbuf.

To choose a format, you can use an appropriate extension in the file name, or explicitly select a format in the combo box. With the first method, if &app; does not recognize an extension, the exported file will be a SVG file. &app; will add an extension to the file name if needed.
You might change the default width and height of the exported image using the appropriate entries.
Postscript and PDF files can also be produced using the File Print... command.

sect1.title: To Print a Chart
sect1.para: To print the chart, choose File Print... .
File Preview opens a window with a preview of the printed output.
To tune the printed output, choose File Page setup... as explained below.

sect2.title: The page setup dialog.
sect2.para: the first tab of the dialog concerns the paper and margins setup. Headers and footers are not supported in the version of &app;

The second tab allows you tio choose the scale of the output. With no scaling or scaling at 100%, the output will have the same size in points as the size in pixels on the screen. If you choose automatic scaling, you can make the output fill the available space either horizontally, vertically, or both (none of the options is equivalent to no scaling).
Printing to more than one page is not supported in this version of &app;

abstract.para: Screenshot of the printing scale page.

sect1.title: To Ask a Question
sect1.para: If you choose Help Ask a question, your mail agent should pop up with a new message to the Gnome Chemistry Utils mailing list.
Another way to get some help is to connect on the #gchemutils channel at irc.gimp.net and ask your question there (if you are not alone on the channel).

sect1.title: To Find the Gnome Chemistry Utils on the Web.
sect1.para: If you choose Help Gnome Chemistry Utils on the web, the default web browser should pop up and display the main page for the Gnome Chemsitry Utils.
The main page is http://gchemutils.nongnu.org and the project page at savannah http://savannah.nongnu.org/projects/gchemutils.

sect1.title: To Report a Bug
sect1.para: To report a bug, you must use the bug page for the Gnome Chemistry Utils at Savannah. You can access it by choosing Help Report Bugs (hopefully you'll have only one at once to report).
You can also type the bug report page address directly in the browser. The bug repository is at https://savannah.nongnu.org/bugs/?group=gchemutils
